summary: This document is an email chain from November 2019 between federal prosecutors (USANYS) discussing scheduling a meeting to catch up on the Epstein investigation. It mentions a recent interview in California that did not yield significant new information, the inability to bring an enticement charge based on timing/location, a victim's uncertainty about pursuing a criminal case, and an upcoming limited proffer session with another individual.

persons.name: USANYS
persons.context: Appears as the sender/recipient in the email chain, discussing case updates and scheduling a meeting to catch up on the Epstein investigation.

events.title: California Interview
events.description: A meeting/interview was held in California with a victim, which did not add significant information. It was determined an enticement charge could not be brought based on timing/location facts, and the victim was still unsure about pursuing a criminal case.

events.title: Limited Proffer Session Scheduled
events.description: An individual (name redacted) is scheduled to come in for a limited proffer session to talk about her background.

keyFacts: Prosecutors determined they 'almost certainly couldn't bring an enticement charge' based on timing and location facts related to a victim's case.
A victim interviewed in California was still not sure whether she wanted to pursue a criminal case; her attorneys were to be circled back with later in November 2019.
The victim did not want to discuss specific conduct during the California meeting, so no additional information was obtained.
Prosecutors were continuing to work on a 'pile of memos' and had scheduled a limited proffer session with another individual for the following week.
The email chain shows internal coordination among prosecutors (USANYS) in November 2019 to discuss case updates.
